poem:
The Air We Breathe  

Invisible culprits drift, uninvited  
between breaths, unasked secrets  
inhaled. Silent saboteurs  
nestle in alveoli, script mutations  
no flame can spark.  
Cities' breaths exhale elegies,  
a shadowed ink  
on DNA's page.  
In the unlit chamber,  
lungs become libraries,  
where air writes  
its ghostly narratives.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. The findings from an investigation into cancer patients around the world helps explain why never-smokers make up a rising proportion of people developing the cancer, a trend the researchers called an “urgent and growing global problem”. Prof". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
